definitions.definition: a hollow space in something solid or in the surface of something

examples.text: He **dug a** deep **hole** in the garden.
The bomb blew a huge hole in the ground.
Water had collected in the holes in the road.
She **drilled a** small **hole** in the wall.
I uprooted the tree and filled the hole with earth.
The snake disappeared down a hole.
There was water in the hole.
We dug a deep hole to bury the animals in.
We used cement to plug the holes.
He managed to dig out a small snow hole.
I've got a chocolate-bar-sized hole in my stomach.

definitions.definition: a space or opening that goes all the way through something

examples.text: We **drilled a hole** through the wall.
The car was riddled with **bullet holes**.
The old blankets were **full of holes**.
There were holes in the knees of his trousers.
There's a **gaping hole** in the ceiling and rain is pouring onto my desk.
She **punched** two **holes** in each sheet of paper.
The children climbed through a hole in the fence.
The fisherman cut a round hole in the ice of the lake.
He had worn a hole in the knees of his trousers.
I used a skewer to make an extra hole in my belt.
The missile had torn a jagged hole in the side of the ship.
The wall was full of bullet holes.

definitions.definition: the home of a small animal

examples.text: a mouse hole
The story begins with Alice falling down a rabbit hole.

definitions.definition: an unpleasant place to live or be in

examples.text: I am not going to bring up my child in this hole.

definitions.definition: a hollow in the ground that you must get the ball into; one of the sections of a golf course with the tee at the beginning and the hole at the end

examples.text: The ball rolled into the hole and she had won.
an eighteen-hole golf course
He liked to play a few holes after work.
She won the first hole.
She won by one hole.

definitions.definition: a fault or weakness in something such as a plan, law or story

examples.text: I don't believe what she says—her story is **full of holes**.
He was found not guilty because of holes in the prosecution case.

definitions.definition: a place or position that needs to be filled because somebody/something is no longer there

examples.text: After his wife left, there was a **gaping hole** in his life.
Buying the new equipment left a big hole in the company's finances.

definitions.definition: a secret advantage, for example a piece of information or a skill, that you are ready to use if you need to
if money burns a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you have it
to get yourself into a bad situation that will be very difficult to get out of

examples.text: He had got himself into a hole and it was going to be difficult to get out of it.
We start the current fiscal year $30 million in the hole.

definitions.definition: to use up a large amount of something that you have, especially money

examples.text: School fees can make a big hole in your savings.

definitions.definition: to find the weak points in something such as a plan, suggestion, etc.

examples.text: It was easy to pick holes in his arguments.

definitions.definition: a person who does not feel happy or comfortable in a particular situation, or who is not suitable for it

wordOrigin: Old English hol (noun), holian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hol (noun) ‘cave’, (adjective) ‘hollow’, and German hohl ‘hollow’, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘cover, conceal’.
